We need to develop a program which reinforces the
idea that a child who has come up to the 6th, 7th,
or 8th grade, in elementary school, has succeeded.
Such programs can do much in winning the pre, or
post elementary school drop-out back to education.
TEEN-AGE
One program area that can play a very important part
in establishing a teen-age drop-out's feeling of inÂ¬
trinsic worth is a series on Adolescent Medicine.
This is a relatively new area of medical practice,
developed originally in Boston, Mass. (Boston
General Hospital) and concentrates specifically on
the physical problems of "growing up." Such programs
could go a long way toward relieving the teen-ager's
fears about being "different," and his tensions
about facing adult responsibility. Such pilot projects
could originate from one or another of the 35 or so
Adolescent Medicine Clinics in the country.
